remixlab.proscene

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.fpstiming.AnimatorObject
      • remixlab.dandelion.core.GrabberScene
        • remixlab.dandelion.branch.GenericScene
          • remixlab.proscene.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PConstants, GenericGrabber<Constants.GlobalAction>, Grabber, Constants, Animator

    public class Scene
extends GenericScene
implements PConstants
    A 2D or 3D interactive Processing Scene. The Scene is a specialization of the GrabberScene, providing an interface between Dandelion and Processing.

    Usage

    To use a Scene you have three choices:
    1. Direct instantiation. In this case you should instantiate your own Scene object at the PApplet.setup() function. See the example BasicUse.
    2. Inheritance. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement GrabberScene.proscenium() which defines the objects in your scene. Just make sure to define the PApplet.draw() method, even if it's empty. See the example AlternativeUse.
    3. External draw handler registration. In addition (not being part of Dandelion), you can even declare an external drawing method and then register it at the Scene with addGraphicsHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. This strategy may be useful when there are multiple viewers sharing the same drawing code. See the example StandardCamera.

    Interactivity mechanisms

    ProScene provides powerful interactivity mechanisms allowing a wide range of scene setups ranging from very simple to complex ones. For convenience, two interaction mechanisms are provided by default: GenericScene.keyboardAgent(), and GenericScene.motionAgent() (which in the desktop version of proscene defaults to a mouseAgent()):
    1. The default keyboard agent provides shortcuts to global keyboard actions such as GrabberScene.drawGrid() or GrabberScene.drawAxes(). See GenericScene.keyboardAgent().
    2. The default mouse agent provides high-level methods to manage Eye and Frame motion actions. Please refer to the MotionAgent and KeyboardAgent API's.

    Animation mechanisms

    ProScene provides three animation mechanisms to define how your scene evolves over time:
    1. Overriding the Dandelion AnimatorObject.animate() method. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement AnimatorObject.animate() which defines how your scene objects evolve over time. See the example Animation.
    2. By checking if the Dandelion AbstractScene's AnimatorObject.timer() was triggered within the frame. See the example Flock.
    3. External animation handler registration. In addition (not being part of Dandelion), you can also declare an external animation method and then register it at the Scene with addAnimationHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. See the example AnimationHandler.

    Scene models

    Each scene instance has a collection of models (see models()). A Model is a PSshape wrapper Grabber (it may thus be manipulated by any Agent), implementing a 'ray-picking' with a color buffer (see pickingBuffer()) technique for easy and precise object selection. Use models(), addModel(Model), removeModels(), hasModel(Model), removeModel(Model), removeModels(), drawModels() and drawModels(PGraphics) for model handling.

      • Scene

        public Scene(PApplet p,
             PGraphics pg,
             int x,
             int y)
        Main constructor defining a left-handed Processing compatible Scene. Calls GrabberScene.setMatrixHelper(MatrixHelper) using a customized MatrixHelper depending on the pg type (see Java2DMatrixHelper and GLMatrixHelper). The constructor instantiates the GrabberScene.inputHandler() and the AnimatorObject.timingHandler(), sets the AXIS and GRID visual hint flags, instantiates the GrabberScene.eye() (a Camera if the Scene is3D() or a Window if the Scene GrabberScene.is2D()). It also instantiates the GenericScene.keyboardAgent() and the mouseAgent(), and finally calls GrabberScene.init().

        An off-screen Processing Scene is defined if pg != p.g. In this case the x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen Scene is expected to be displayed, e.g., for instance with a call to Processing the image(img, x, y) function. If pg == p.g) (which defines an on-screen Scene, see also GrabberScene.isOffscreen()), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values).

        See Also:
        GenericScene.GenericScene(), Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphics)

        public PGraphics pg()
        Returns the PGraphics instance this Scene is related to. It may be the PApplets one, if the Scene is on-screen or an user-defined if the Scene GrabberScene.isOffscreen().

      • addGraphicsHandler

                               String methodName)

      • pixelDepth

        public float pixelDepth(Point pixel)
        Description copied from class: GrabberScene
        Returns the depth (z-value) of the object under the pixel.

        The z-value ranges in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D Note that this value is not a linear interpolation between Camera.zNear() and Camera.zFar(); z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z'); where z' is the distance from the point you project to the camera, along the Camera.viewDirection(). See the gluUnProject man page for details.

        Specified by:
        pixelDepth in class GrabberScene

      • disableDepthTest

        public void disableDepthTest()
        Description copied from class: GrabberScene
        Disables z-buffer.
        Specified by:
        disableDepthTest in class GrabberScene

      • enableDepthTest

        public void enableDepthTest()
        Description copied from class: GrabberScene
        Enables z-buffer.
        Specified by:
        enableDepthTest in class GrabberScene

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls GrabberScene.preDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If GrabberScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), GrabberScene.preDraw(), GrabberScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), GrabberScene.isOffscreen()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls GrabberScene.postDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If GrabberScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        See Also:
        pre(), GrabberScene.preDraw(), GrabberScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), GrabberScene.isOffscreen()

      • post

        public void post()

      • beginDraw

        public void beginDraw()
        Only if the Scene GrabberScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just after the pg() beginDraw() method. Simply calls GrabberScene.preDraw().

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), GrabberScene.preDraw(), GrabberScene.postDraw(), pre(), endDraw(), GrabberScene.isOffscreen()

      • endDraw

        public void endDraw()
        Only if the Scene GrabberScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just before pg() endDraw() method. Simply calls GrabberScene.postDraw().
        See Also:
        draw(), GrabberScene.preDraw(), GrabberScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), pre(), GrabberScene.isOffscreen()

        public boolean removeModel(Model model)
        Remove the model from the scene.
        See Also:
        models(), drawModels(), drawModels(PGraphics), addModel(Model)

      • removeModels

        public void removeModels()

      • drawModels

        public boolean drawModels()
        Draw all scene models(). Same as: for (Model model : models()) model.draw(pg());.

        Returns true if at least a model get drawn.

        Note that drawModels() should be call by you, most likely from within your sketch main drawing loop (i.e., The P).

        See Also:
        models(), pg(), drawModels(PGraphics), addModel(Model), removeModel(Model), Model.draw(PGraphics)

      • drawModels

        public boolean drawModels(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Draw all models() into the given pgraphics. No pgraphics.beginDraw()/endDraw() calls take place. This method allows shader chaining.

        Returns true if at least a model get drawn.

        Note that drawModels(pickingBuffer()) (which enables 'picking' of the models using a 'ray-picking' technique is called by post().

        Parameters:
        pgraphics -
        See Also:
        models(), drawModels(), addModel(Model), removeModel(Model), Model.draw(PGraphics)

      • matrixHelper

        public MatrixHelper matrixHelper(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Returns a new matrix helper for the given pgraphics. Rarely needed.

        Note that the current scene matrix helper may be retrieved by GrabberScene.matrixHelper().

        See Also:
        GrabberScene.matrixHelper(), GrabberScene.setMatrixHelper(MatrixHelper), drawModels(), drawModels(PGraphics), applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame)

      • bindMatrices

        public void bindMatrices(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Same as matrixHelper(pgraphics).bind(false). Set the pgraphics matrices by calling MatrixHelper.loadProjection(boolean) and MatrixHelper.loadModelView(boolean) (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics).

        This method doesn't perform any computation, but simple retrieve the current matrices whose actual computation has been updated in GrabberScene.preDraw().

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(PGraphics pgraphics,
                                Frame frame)
        Apply the local transformation defined by the given frame on the given pgraphics. This method doesn't call bindMatrices(PGraphics) which should be called manually (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics). Needed by applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame).
        See Also:
        applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame), bindMatrices(PGraphics)

      • applyWorldTransformation

        public void applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics pgraphics,
                                     Frame frame)
        Apply the global transformation defined by the given frame on the given pgraphics. This method doesn't call bindMatrices(PGraphics) which should be called manually (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics). Needed by Model.draw(PGraphics)
        See Also:
        Model.draw(PGraphics), applyTransformation(PGraphics, Frame), bindMatrices(PGraphics)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(Eye eye,
                    float scale)
        Description copied from class: GrabberScene
        Draws a representation of the camera in the 3D virtual world.

        The near and far planes are drawn as quads, the frustum is drawn using lines and the camera up vector is represented by an arrow to disambiguate the drawing.

        When drawFarPlane is false, only the near plane is drawn. scale can be used to scale the drawing: a value of 1.0 (default) will draw the Camera's frustum at its actual size.

        Note: The drawing of a Scene's own Scene.camera() should not be visible, but may create artifacts due to numerical imprecisions.

        Specified by:
        drawEye in class GrabberScene

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(KeyFrameInterpolator kfi,
                     int mask,
                     int nbFrames,
                     float scale)
        Description copied from class: GrabberScene
        Draws the path used to interpolate the KeyFrameInterpolator.frame()

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), a camera representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), oriented axes are regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and cameras
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axes

        In the case where camera or axes are drawn, nbFrames controls the number of objects (axes or camera) drawn between two successive keyFrames. When nbFrames = 1, only the path KeyFrames are drawn. nbFrames = 2 also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30. nbFrames should divide 30 so that an object is drawn for each KeyFrame. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the camera and axes drawing. A value of GrabberScene.radius() should give good results.

        Specified by:
        drawPath in class GrabberScene

        Specified by:
